messages.subject: Re: a little more direction
messages.msgSnippet: Craig, That s correct. I have no attribution or paper and have not submitted this tsuba for paper. I found 4 or 5 Kunitomo s and needed some help as to which
messages.messageBody:
Craig,

That's correct. I have no attribution or paper and have not
submitted this tsuba for paper. I found 4 or 5 Kunitomo's and needed
some help as to which one or ones to study.

I appreciate the help, if you think of anything else, let me know.

Elliott

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] a little more direction
messages.msgSnippet: To clarify a bit on the Kunitomo tsuba, I owned that one for a number of years. I bought it from Skip Holbrook, and that s where the attribution came from, I
messages.messageBody:
To clarify a bit on the "Kunitomo" tsuba, I owned that one for a number of
years. I bought it from Skip Holbrook, and that's where the attribution came
from, I think because of the sahari inlay work reminding one of similar work
by the Kunitomo gunsmiths. No one who saw this tsuba, Jim Gilbert, Bob
Haynes, etc. could think of anything better to call it. I'm pretty sure that
Bob said he did not recognize the kao.

No papers, unless Elliot has taken that step ... it would be interesting to
see what 'box' the experts would put it in.

Craig

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] a little more direction
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Elliot, For the Myochin I will definitely go with Haru. Myochin Ki Muneharu. Pete s already had a good go at describing this smith I think. In regards to
messages.messageBody:
Hi Elliot, For the Myochin I will definitely go with Haru. Myochin Ki
Muneharu. Pete's already had a good go at describing this smith I think.
In regards to the Kunitomo, I have 5 listed, and I am not sure of this
one myself. I see no signature so I am assuming it was sold to you with
an attribution, or is papered ?

Cheers

Richard

messages.msgSnippet: Thanks Pete, I just needed a little prod to remember what you found. I saved all of the messages and a copy of the scan from your album. All is well with the
messages.messageBody:
Thanks Pete,

I just needed a little 'prod' to remember what you found. I saved
all of the messages and a copy of the scan from your album.

All is well with the Myochin. Now to the other's.

Thanks,

Elliott

Perhaps you missed my post on this but if you go back there is some
information for you and by the way if you click the link the picture
is of your tsuba prior to having to ume (gold inserts) placed.

messages.subject: a little more direction
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all, This is a continuance of my questions and some new ones.... In my photo album, I have added new pictures (#1 and #2) of a Kunitomo piece. I am
messages.messageBody:
Hi all,

This is a continuance of my 'questions' and some new ones....

In my photo album, I have added new pictures (#1 and #2) of a
Kunitomo piece. I am confused as to which path to follow. I am open
to direction.

Photo's #5 and #6 are the best close-up's of the Myochin mei I can
get with my lack of good photo equipment. Hopefully these will help
in deciding which one (Muneharu or Muneyoshi). And maybe Santa Claus
will be good to me and bring me a new camera with Macro lens.

Last, I have a mei that I can't seem to find in any volume I have.
The mei is 'Nagoya Tsunenari'. He also signed 'Bishu Mihara Ju
Nagoya Tsunenari'. I can't find him anywhere.

As always, thank you all for your help.

Elliott
